awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Algorithms for Optimal Adaptive Enrichment Design in Randomized Trial
awd_abstract_narration:
The increasing costs of clinical trials negatively impact public health by reducing drug companies' willingness to undertake clinical trials and delaying new drug development.  A typical clinical trial may cost millions of U.S. dollars, depending on therapeutic areas and scientific goals. In designing clinical trials, one needs to balance (typically conflicting) aims in scientific/biological aspects, statistical power, and cost. This decision-making problem is very complicated in personalized medicine, where multiple subpopulations need to be simultaneously considered. Existing approaches for designing adaptive trials either do not involve optimization of objectives or optimize in very restrictive settings. This project considers adaptive enrichment design, a flexible trial design framework that allows trial administrators to adjust patient enrollment rules during the trials. It has been shown to often provide superior cost effectiveness and better statistical power. The research aims to design new methods and algorithms to optimize adaptive enrichment design.

The optimal design problem with two planning stages and two subpopulations is formulated as a large-scale linear programming model, which can be solved by off-the-shelf LP solvers. Due to the exponentially increasing LP size, such LP solvers cannot be directly applied to the practical situations with more planning stages and subpopulations. This project will develop specialized algorithms and modelling techniques to fully exploit problem structures to solve two-stage two-subpopulation models much faster, and extend them to larger models previously regarded as unsolvable. Furthermore, user-friendly open-source software will be developed to enable scientists to construct their own optimal adaptive enrichment designs.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Overview

This project was dedicated to advancing algorithmic methods motivated from  optimizing adaptive enrichment designs in clinical trials, with a focus on improving decision-making in healthcare and clinical research. The primary objective was to develop sophisticated algorithms that enhance the efficiency and fairness of randomized trials, particularly for subgroups of patients who may benefit differently from treatments.

Through a series of algorithmic innovations, we aimed to provide researchers and clinicians with tools that allow for more precise patient stratification, dynamic trial adjustments, and improved treatment selection based on real-time data. This approach is critical for increasing the success rates of clinical trials and ensuring that patients receive the most appropriate treatments while reducing unnecessary interventions. In addition, a particular focus was to improve the fairness of the clinical regime to ensure under-represented minority groups were not harmed by the decisions.

Intellectual Merit

The intellectual contributions of this project span both theoretical advancements in optimization and practical applications in clinical trial design.

  1. Sparse Linear Bandit for Small Action Spaces: One of the key innovations, published in the Journal of the American Statistical Association, introduced a sparse linear bandit algorithm that is nearly independent of dimensionality. This algorithm is particularly useful for optimizing clinical trial decisions when the number of actions (such as treatments) is small but the dimension of patient data is high. By using best subset selection techniques, this approach allows for efficient decision-making even in high-dimensional settings, ensuring that the best treatment strategies are identified quickly and with minimal computational overhead. 
  2. Fairness-Oriented Algorithms for Treatment Rules: Another significant outcome of this project is the development of fairness-oriented learning algorithms for individualized treatment decisions, which was published in Journal of the American Statistical Association. This research introduces novel methods to mitigate biases in treatment allocation, ensuring that patients from various demographic subgroups are treated equitably. These algorithms are particularly valuable in clinical trials where ethical concerns about fairness and equal access to treatments are paramount. 
  3. Optimization Under Misspecified Regimes: In the context of uncertain or misspecified environments, our work on data-driven compositional optimization (published in Operations Research) provides new methodologies for decision-making in clinical settings where perfect information is not available. This research has implications for trials where patient responses are unpredictable, offering more robust algorithms that adapt to evolving data and prevent incorrect conclusions about treatment efficacy.
  4. Robust Matrix Estimations and Frank-Wolfe Algorithms: In collaboration with other researchers, we developed robust matrix estimation techniques that can be applied for  optimizing trial designs. Published in Machine Learning, this work integrates the Frank-Wolfe algorithm, improving the efficiency of statistical inference in adaptive enrichment designs. This advancement helps clinical researchers more effectively analyze interim data and adjust trial parameters, thus leading to more accurate and timely decisions. 

Broader Impacts

The clinical and societal implications of this project are significant:

  • Enhanced Precision in Clinical Trials: By introducing advanced algorithms for adaptive enrichment designs, this project contributes to more personalized and effective treatment strategies in clinical trials. These tools allow clinicians to dynamically adjust trials based on patient responses, thereby increasing the likelihood of successful outcomes and minimizing risks for patients who may not benefit from certain treatments.
  • Improved Fairness and Equity in Healthcare: The development of fairness-oriented algorithms ensures that treatment decisions in clinical trials are made without bias, promoting equity in healthcare. These methods can be used to address disparities in treatment access and outcomes, particularly for underrepresented or vulnerable populations.
  • Robust Decision-Making Under Uncertainty: In clinical settings where patient responses are unpredictable, our work on optimization in misspecified regimes provides clinicians with reliable tools for making informed decisions. This is crucial for improving trial outcomes, especially when dealing with rare diseases or novel treatments where historical data may be sparse.
  • Educational and Workforce Development: The project also contributed to the training of graduate and undergraduate students in machine learning, optimization, and statistical methods. These students have gained hands-on experience in developing and applying algorithms, preparing them to become leaders in both academia and industry.

Key Outcomes

Key accomplishments of this project include:

  • Development of a sparse linear bandit algorithm for optimizing decisions in clinical trials with complex patient data.
  • Introduction of fairness-oriented learning algorithms to improve the ethical distribution of treatments in randomized trials.
  • Advances in robust optimization techniques that enable more reliable decision-making in uncertain clinical environments.
  • The creation of algorithms for learning Nash equilibria and optimizing treatment assortments in multi-agent settings.

Concluding Statement

Overall, this project has significantly advanced the algorithmic foundations of adaptive enrichment design in clinical trials, contributing to both intellectual advancements in optimization and real-world applications in healthcare. Our findings have the potential to revolutionize how clinical trials are conducted, ensuring more personalized, equitable, and effective treatment strategies that ultimately improve patient outcomes and enhance public health.
